nd
since programs by themselves can’t produce minds, it follows that the
way the brain does it can’t be by simply instantiating a computer pro-
gram. (Everything, by the way, instantiates some program or other, and
brains are no exception. So in that trivial sense brains, like everything
else,  are  digital  computers.)  And  it  also  follows  that  if  you  wanted  to
build a machine to produce mental states, a thinking machine, you could-
n’t do it solely in virtue of the fact that your machi
